Hi All:
=A0
=A0 Heianjo are complex.=A0 For a start, most Heianjo (real Hei=
anjo and not Edo period copies) are Momoyama period or earlier.=A0 They wer=
e mainly made just for a hundred years or so, basically the 16th century.=
=A0 The earlier pieces are sometimes called Onin, but even if you include t=
his group, you still only get the period around 1450-1600.=A0 That means th=
at they are old.=A0 Many were lacquered.=A0 Some were well preserved some w=
ere not.=A0 The lacquer is part of the overall gestalt.=A0 If you see a hun=
dred Heianjo tsuba, 25 or so will be lacquered, of which 5 will be in excel=
lent condition, 10 will be decently preserved, 5 will be in need of varying=
 degrees of restoration and 5 will be dead.

Cheers,

Shirogitsune
